content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in seconds.” The heading for row 2 is “p of t, in feet.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. p of t is negative 25. Column 2. t is 5. p of t is negative 20. Column 3. t is 10. p of t is negative 14. Column 4. t is 15. p of t is negative 8. Column 5. t is 20. p of t is negative 2.5." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(seconds)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(feet)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>25</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The position of a particle, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds and <math alttext="p of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet. Selected values of <math alttext="p of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use a midpoint Riemann sum with two subintervals of equal length and values from the table to approximate the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 20, of, p of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a two row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in seconds.” The heading for row 2 is “p of t, in feet.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. p of t is negative 25. Column 2. t is 5. p of t is negative 20. Column 3. t is 10. p of t is negative 14. Column 4. t is 15. p of t is negative 8. Column 5. t is 20. p of t is negative 2.5." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" frame="solid" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(seconds)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mo>⁢</mo></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>15</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>20</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtext>(feet)</mtext></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>25</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The position of a particle, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in seconds and <math alttext="p of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet. Selected values of <math alttext="p of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use a midpoint Riemann sum with two subintervals of equal length and values from the table to approximate the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 20, of, p of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(b) Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="p prime of 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> using the average rate of change of <math alttext="p of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="5 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Indicate units of measure.

(c) Interpret the meaning of <math alttext="p prime of 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(d) Must there exist a value of <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 less than b, less than 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>b</mi><mo><</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="p prime of b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is equal to the average rate of change of <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(e) Find <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 5, of, p prime of, open parenthesis, 2 t plus 5, close parenthesis, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Let <math alttext="h of x equals, the integral from 3 to 5 x, of, p of, open parenthesis, 4 t, close parenthesis, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>p</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="h prime of 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(g) The velocity of a second particle, <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, can be modeled by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="g of 1 equals negative 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g prime of 1 equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="g double prime of 1 equals 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the speed of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing or decreasing at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(h) Let <math alttext="y equals f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals negative 2 times x cubed, times y squared, minus 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="f of negative 1 equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at the point <math alttext="with coordinates negative 1 comma 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.1: Interpreting the Meaning of the Derivative in Context

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
